author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Met Opera Taps German Conductor as Next Chorus Director
description: Tilman Michael, who leads the Frankfurt Opera’s chorus, will succeed the veteran conductor Donald Palumbo, who steps down this season after 17 years.
content: The chorus master at the Metropolitan Opera has one of the company’s most demanding jobs. There are singers to corral, notes to correct and centuries-old scores to pore over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Agee
title: In These Books, the Parents Are the Problem
description: The children in three illustrated satirical tales are up against something far more complex than ogres, witches and big bad wolves.
content: Children’s books have long featured pint-size heroes overcoming fierce antagonists: ogres, witches and big bad wolves. So it comes as no surprise that a similar drama occurs in these three stories. Only here, children are up against something far more complex: their parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Interest Rates and the Election
description: The Fed is expected to cut rates soon. Doing so could pull it into a partisan fight.
content: The Federal Reserve is in a tough spot. It expects to cut interest rates soon. But doing so before an election will yank the apolitical central bank directly into a partisan fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How to Make Bubble Tea
description: A winning essay by Hanyi Zhou, age 14.
content: This essay, by Hanyi Zhou, 14, of Hong Kong, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Can You Make or Fix With Your Hands?
description: Did you know that manual activities like cooking, making art, playing a musical instrument and building things can be good for your brain?
content: How often do you work with your hands — that is, use them for activities that don’t involve typing, pushing buttons or tapping screens?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A 15-Minute, Five-Ingredient Childhood Favorite
description: Priya Krishna’s headily spiced everyday dal is essential comfort food.
content: Every culture has its comfort dishes, the ones with powers to calm the frazzled, succor the ailing and mollify the homesick. Chicken soup and blintzes with cottage cheese and cinnamon sugar whisk me right back to my Brooklyn Jewish childhood, and I still regularly self-medicate with both of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Chides Trump for Ignoring Expanded Gag Order
description: Colbert said that after the order was amended, the former president “paused, listened to his critics and launched another attack on the judge’s daughter, this time with photos.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What Janet Yellen Needs to Tell China’s Leaders
description: The economic course correction that the United States wants would also help average Chinese people.
content: It would be great if Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen had a copy of “The Portable Karl Marx” with her on her trip to China this week. She could quote from it to the Chinese leaders, whose amended constitution promises to follow “the guidance of Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought, Deng Xiaoping Theory, the Theory of Three Represents, the Scientific Outlook on Development and Xi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump and R.N.C. Announce a $65.6 Million Haul in March
description: The new numbers help the former president narrow the financial gap with President Biden, who had amassed $155 million with the Democratic Party at the end of February.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump had the best fund-raising month of his 2024 campaign now that he’s working in tandem with the Republican National Committee, pulling in $65.6 million in March, the party announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd, Abu Bakr Bashir, Riley Mellen, Aaron Boxerman and Aric Toler
title: They Had Just Delivered Tons of Food. Then Their Convoy Was Hit.
description: The deaths of World Central Kitchen workers pushed the number of aid employees killed during the war in Gaza to at least 196, according to the U.N. secretary general, António Guterres.
content: Lalzawmi Frankcom’s text message was short and sweet: a heart emoji reply at 10:38 p.m. on Sunday to her friend Josh Phelps, who had sent along photos of their humanitarian work together on a reservation in South Dakota.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Wisconsin Voters Approve Bans on Private Aid for Election Offices
description: Wisconsin’s Republican-led Legislature proposed changing the State Constitution to restrict private funding and staffing of election offices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Heaney
title: I’m a Doctor. Dengue Fever Took Even Me by Surprise on Vacation.
description: Without urgent reforms to how we educate travelers, doctors, nurses and others, we are doomed to miss textbook dengue cases.
content: I hate mosquitoes so much that I take my own bug repellent to parties. But in early March, on a trip with my partner to the idyllic island of Curaçao off the coast of Venezuela, I was caught off guard by insect bites after our bed-and-breakfast hosts said that mosquitoes didn’t usually appear until late summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: What We Know About the Earthquake in Taiwan
description: The quake set off aftershocks and damaged dozens of buildings, killing nine people and leaving many injured or trapped.
content: A powerful 7.4-magnitude earthquake that rocked Taiwan during the morning commute on Wednesday was the strongest quake to hit the island in 25 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How to Wrap a Dumpling
description: A winning essay by Jacob Wang, age 16.
content: This essay, by Jacob Wang, 16, of Godalming, England, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Psychedelic Rock and Tammy’s Lunch Box: A Small City’s Big Eclipse Plans
description: Let the big cities have their eclipse mega-events. In Plattsburgh, N.Y., success looks different for everyone stopping to look up.
content: There were five cars in the crowded driveway, one for each of the young men in the cramped basement running through their band’s new songs. Their last real gig was on New Year’s Eve, and now it was late March. The keyboard player was keeping an eye on the time because he had to get to a piano lesson soon. He’s the teacher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Ugandan Court Upholds Draconian Anti-Gay Law
description: The law, which includes the death penalty as a punishment in some cases, has been strongly condemned, including by the United States.
content: Uganda’s Constitutional Court on Wednesday largely upheld a sweeping anti-gay law that President Yoweri Museveni signed last year, undermining the efforts of activists and rights groups to abolish legislation that drew worldwide condemnation and strained the East African nation’s relationship with the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rojas
title: ‘Carefluencers’ Are Helping Older Loved Ones, and Posting About It
description: On TikTok and Instagram, people are sharing what it’s like to take care of relatives who have reached their final years.
content: On the east side of San Jose, Calif., there is an abuela who seems to have more grandchildren than she can count.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jim Tankersley, Stella Tan, Mary Wilson, Michael Simon Johnson, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Accidental Tax Cutter in Chief
description: President Biden says he wants to rake in more money from corporations and high earners. But so far, he has cut more taxes than he’s raised.
content: In his campaign for re-election, President Biden has said that raising taxes on the wealthy and on big corporations is at the heart of his agenda. But under his watch, overall net taxes have decreased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lachlan Cartwright
title: What I Saw Working at The National Enquirer During Donald Trump’s Rise
description: Inside the notorious “catch and kill” campaign that now stands at the heart of the former president’s legal trial.
content: On Tuesday, April 4, 2023, I was outside Manhattan criminal court. It was a sunny spring day, and the Secret Service and the Police Department had blocked off the streets with barricades. The sidewalks were clogged with news crews from around the world. Supporters of Donald Trump roamed a pen that was set up to house them. Eventually, the former president was rushed out of the courthouse after being charged by Alvin Bragg, the district attorney of Manhattan, with 34 counts of falsifying business records. His convoy departed to cheers from fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: An Ozempic Relative Slowed Parkinson’s Disease in a Small Study
description: The trial lasted only one year but offered embers of hope to some experts.
content: In 1817, James Parkinson expressed a hope about the disease that is named after him. He thought that at some point there would be a discovery and “the progress of the disease may be stopped.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Necessary Discomfort of Jerrod Carmichael’s ‘Reality’
description: Jerrod Carmichael’s stock in trade is the exploitation of the awkward.
content: The comedian Jerrod Carmichael spends a remarkable amount of time in his new HBO series, “Jerrod Carmichael Reality Show,” with his head in his hands like Henri Vidal’s 19th-century statue of Cain after he has killed his brother Abel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel, Cassandra Vinograd and Erica L. Green
title: Biden says he is ‘outraged’ by the attack on an aid convoy, after Israel’s military says it was a mistake.
description: In a sharply worded statement, Mr. Biden said that Israel had not done enough to protect civilians and noted that the deaths were not a “stand-alone incident.”
content: President Biden said he was “outraged and heartbroken” by the killing of seven humanitarian aid workers in a strike by Israeli forces, strongly condemning the attack just hours after Israel’s top military commander acknowledged its military had made a “grave mistake.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Switching From iPhone to Android Is Easy. It’s the Aftermath That Stings.
description: Even if you manage to ditch your iPhone, Apple’s hooks are still there.
content: When I temporarily switched from an iPhone to an Android phone last week, I was bracing for a world of hurt. I’ve owned only Apple phones ever since buying the first-generation iPhone in 2007. And, like many, I’ve bought other Apple products that pair nicely, including AirPods, an Apple Watch and an iPad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Did One Guy Just Stop a Huge Cyberattack?
description: A Microsoft engineer noticed something was off on a piece of software he worked on. He soon discovered someone was probably trying to gain access to computers all over the world.
content: The internet, as anyone who works deep in its trenches will tell you, is not a smooth, well-oiled machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How to Make the Perfect Sandwich
description: A winning essay by Jackson DeNichilo, age 15.
content: This essay, by Jackson DeNichilo, 15, of Fallston, Md., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Choice Cuts
description: Alex Eaton-Salners leaves space for the unknown.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: For Red State Holdouts Like Kansas, Is Expanding Medicaid Within Reach?
description: As Southern states reconsider Medicaid expansion, Gov. Laura Kelly of Kansas is pushing her own plan meant to appeal to conservatives. So far, success has been elusive.
content: As lawmakers in a nearby hearing room debated last month whether to support her legislation to expand Medicaid, Gov. Laura Kelly of Kansas dared the state’s Republican House speaker to hold a vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grayson Haver Currin
title: Alice Randall Made Country History. Black Women Are Helping Tell Hers.
description: In “My Black Country,” the musician and author who cracked a Nashville color barrier is telling her story — and hearing her songs reimagined.
content: The country singer Rissi Palmer could not understand why Alice Randall was emailing her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: At New Directors/New Films, the Kids Are Not All Right (Nobody Really Is)
description: This year’s edition of the festival tends toward familiar art-house fare, but there are standouts in which characters young and old grapple with childhood.
content: The terrific Ukrainian documentary “Intercepted” — screening in this year’s New Directors/New Films festival — is an austere and harrowing chronicle of life, death and indifference. For roughly 90 minutes, it juxtaposes images from everyday life in Ukraine with audio gleaned from phone calls between Russian soldiers and their families. As the camera steadily focuses on the devastations of war, you hear these soldiers talking about what they’re doing, how they’re feeling, what they ate, what they plundered and who they killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: 100,000 Live Salmon Spilled Off a Truck. Most Landed in a Creek and Lived.
description: A tanker carrying young salmon crashed. But most of the fish flopped into a creek and “hit the water running,” a wildlife official said.
content: On a recent morning in March, while dew was still on the road, there occurred the salmon smolt mishap of Northeast Oregon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica M. Goldstein
title: Julia Stiles Wanted to Be Just Like Kat Stratford, Too
description: Twenty-five years after “10 Things I Hate About You” made her stand out among a generation of young stars, she’s stayed true to the ideals of her most famous character.
content: Julia Stiles starts lunch with a disclaimer: “I’m kind of like a bundle of emotions, because I have a 5-month-old baby and I went into directing my first movie.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Quick Skillet Turkey Dinner You’ll Make Over and Over
description: This easy Melissa Clark recipe, inspired by the zesty, pungent flavors of larb, turns unassuming ground turkey into a star.
content: Bunches of fresh mint and piles of sugar snap peas are still weeks away from showing up at my local farmers’ market, but April’s lengthening days and warming temperatures already have me craving that classic spring pairing. Luckily, they can also be foraged right now at the supermarket down the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Hualien County Is a Quiet, Scenic Tourist Destination
description: The area, known for a famous gorge and aquamarine waters, sits on several active faults.
content: Hualien County on Taiwan’s east coast is a scenic, sleepy tourist area tucked away from the island’s urban centers, with a famous gorge and aquamarine waters. It also happens to sit on several active faults, making it prone to earthquakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: She’s Shaking Up Classical Music While Confronting Illness
description: The pianist Alice Sara Ott, who makes her New York Philharmonic debut this week, is upending concert culture — and defying stereotypes about multiple sclerosis.
content: The pianist Alice Sara Ott, barefoot and wearing a silver bracelet, was smiling and singing to herself the other day as she practiced a jazzy passage of Ravel at Steinway Hall in Midtown Manhattan. A Nintendo Switch, which she uses to warm up her hands, was by her side (another favored tool is a Rubik’s Cube). A shot of espresso sat untouched on the floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Another Poll Shows Biden Trailing in Key States
description: The findings from the Wall Street Journal’s poll of seven battleground states echo other recent surveys.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump still leads President Biden in the battleground states likeliest to decide the presidency, according to polls from The Wall Street Journal in seven key states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: How Beagles and a Fever Dream Made Rebel Wilson a Star
description: The actress, known for roles in the “Pitch Perfect” movies, gets vulnerable about her weight loss, sexuality and money in her new memoir, “Rebel Rising.”
content: About five years ago, when she was 39, the actress Rebel Wilson faced a dilemma. She had just had a string of successes, having made $20 million for her comic roles in “Pitch Perfect 3,” “Isn’t It Romantic” and “The Hustle.” But a visit to a fertility doctor had filled her with self-doubt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. and China Continue to Talk, but Economic Divide Remains Wide
description: Election-year rancor will make it difficult for Washington and Beijing to find areas of cooperation on trade and investment.
content: When Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen traveled to Beijing last summer, her mission was to re-establish a dialogue between the world’s largest economies and stabilize a relationship that appeared to have reached rock bottom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Shirley Horn
description: The pianist and vocalist was at once magnetically powerful and laid-back, glamorous and understated. A mix of musicians, writers and radio personalities share their favorites.
content: We’ve spent five minutes with icons of the avant-garde, big-band heroes and saxophone titans. This time around, we’re putting the spotlight on one of jazz history’s rarest talents, the pianist and vocalist Shirley Horn, who would have turned 90 next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What Tesla’s Troubles Signal for the E.V. Revolution
description: The carmaker’s disappointing results point to slowing demand and a “sharp deterioration in growth” that extends beyond Elon Musk’s company.
content: Wall Street has sounded the alarm for weeks that the transition to electric vehicles may be stalling, despite billions in government subsidies and huge investments by auto giants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I Inherited a Nazi Helmet From My Husband. What Should I Do With It?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what to do with a politically charged heirloom.
content: I own a Nazi helmet my husband, now deceased, inherited from his father. For a long time it didn’t bother me; it only left me wondering about the soldier who wore it. But with the resurgence in white supremacy, neo-fascism and antisemitism, I am now very uncomfortable with it. I can’t seem to figure out what to do with it. I don’t think a museum would be interested in it. I certainly would never sell it, being uneasy about who might buy it. Donating it to a theater costume shop is a possibility. Or should I save it as a piece of history for my great-grandchildren to learn from? — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How California’s Fire Season Might Shape Up This Year
description: It’s been a rainy winter, but that won’t necessarily mean fewer wildfires.
content: Luckily for us, the 2023 fire season in California was exceptionally mild.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: 2 Brothers in Trump Media Insider-Trading Scheme Plead Guilty
description: Michael and Gerald Shvartsman, who had originally pleaded not guilty to securities fraud charges, each pleaded guilty to one count of securities fraud.
content: Two brothers from Miami pleaded guilty on Wednesday in federal court in Manhattan for their role in a nearly $23 million insider-trading scheme surrounding the 2021 announcement that former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company planned to merge with a cash-rich shell company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Many Democrats Are Worried Trump Will Beat Biden. This One Isn’t.
description: Simon Rosenberg has spent the past two years telling Democrats they need to calm down. His Biden-will-win prediction is his next big test.
content: Simon Rosenberg was right about the congressional elections of 2022. All the conventional wisdom — the polls, the punditry, the fretting by fellow Democrats — revolved around the expectation of a big red wave and a Democratic wipeout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Have the Brands Gone Too Far? Boston Marathoners Think So.
description: Runners are disappointed that the new finisher medals feature a large bank logo across the bottom. “This isn’t a turkey trot.”
content: Cathy Connor loves the Boston Marathon. She loves the camaraderie. She loves the mystique of the event, which dates to 1897 as the world’s oldest annual marathon. She loves the idea that she gets to run the same rolling course that has been conquered by greats like Kathrine Switzer, Meb Keflezighi and Des Linden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: With Abortion on the Ballot, Trump Says He’ll Address the Issue ‘Next Week’
description: Two rulings on abortion by the Florida Supreme Court shook up the race in Donald Trump’s home state and present a potential new vulnerability for his campaign.
content: Donald J. Trump, appearing in two crucial swing states on Tuesday, avoided discussing abortion but teased that he would address the issue “next week,” once again demurring on taking a clear position on the issue after two Florida Supreme Court rulings shook up the 2024 campaign in the former president’s home state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meaghan Tobin, Victoria Kim, Chris Buckley, Mike Ives, Siyi Zhao and John Yoon
title: Taiwan’s Strongest Earthquake in 25 Years Kills 9 and Injures Hundreds
description: The magnitude-7.4 quake was followed by more than 200 aftershocks. Dozens of people were trapped. Two buildings in the city of Hualien teetered perilously.
content: The first quake was alarming enough — a rumble more powerful than anything felt in Taiwan for a quarter-century, lasting for more than a minute on Wednesday morning, knocking belongings and even whole buildings askew. It was so strong it set off tsunami warnings in Japan, China and the Philippines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: Desert Drives and Sea Lion Dives: The Enduring Draws of La Paz, Mexico
description: New hotels and destination-worthy restaurants now complement the ever-appealing outdoors surrounding La Paz, the capital of Baja California Sur.
content: For our last night in La Paz, Mexico, we kept it simple: A couple of cans of cold Pacifico, a bench on the malecón, the city’s waterfront promenade, and the sunset glowing orange over the shimmering silver-blue Sea of Cortez. My husband, Alex, and I had spent nearly a week taking scenic desert drives and lazy city strolls, visiting stunning beaches and mountains, and enjoying a steady diet of fish tacos and mezcalitas. But now we were salt-coated and sinking into a blissful exhaustion that comes only after a day spent scuba diving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden and Corporate America? It’s ‘Complicated.’
description: The president has courted executives with long listening sessions and sustained outreach, but frustrated many with his tax plans and regulations.
content: In the days before delivering his State of the Union speech last month, President Biden called the chief executives of General Motors and Cisco Systems to ask their advice on the state of the American economy and share how he planned to talk about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Inflation Cools in Eurozone, Nearing Central Bank’s Target
description: Prices in the countries that use the euro rose 2.4 percent in the year through March, coming closer to the European Central Bank’s 2 percent inflation target.
content: The annual inflation rate across most economies in Europe eased for the third month in a row, nearing the target set by the European Central Bank. Consumer prices in the 20 countries that use the euro rose 2.4 percent in the year through March, down from 2.6 percent the month before, the European Union reported on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.2 Million Homes in New York, Georgia and Utah
description: A 19th-century farmhouse with a guesthouse in Leeds, an 1850 townhouse in Savannah and a 1927 home in Salt Lake City.
content: This expansive property is in a small hamlet in Greene County, about 15 minutes from the town of Greenville, which has a supermarket, a farm supply store and a drive-in movie theater, and within a 20-minute drive of several antique and home décor stores. It is half an hour from the city of Hudson and from Olana State Historic Site, the former home and studio of the painter Frederic Edwin Church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman and Clement Pascal
title: When Latin America Became the Seat of Modernity
description: A new MoMA exhibition looks at design from six countries, spanning 1940 to 1980. Some beautiful chairs tell the tale.
content: Lina Bo Bardi, the great Italian-Brazilian architect, liked to say we all invent architecture just by climbing a stair, crossing a room, opening a door or sitting down in a chair. All of “these little gestures,” she said, along with the objects they involve, are richly endowed with meaning and memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Christopher Durang, Playwright Who Mixed High Art and Low Humor, Dies at 75
description: In a career spanning more than 40 years, he established himself as a hyperliterate jester and an anarchic clown.
content: Christopher Durang, a Tony Award-winning playwright and a master satirist, died on Tuesday night at his home in Pipersville, Pa., in Bucks County. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney Fends Off Activist Investor for Second Time in 2 Years
description: Nelson Peltz had campaigned for two seats on Disney’s board of directors, as he sought to shake up the company’s growth plan.
content: The activist investor Nelson Peltz and Ike Perlmutter, the former chairman of Marvel Entertainment, have failed to infiltrate Disney’s board for the second time in two years, losing a tensely fought contest for support of the company’s shareholders as part of a campaign to alter its direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Thursday Briefing: Ukraine Lowers the Draft Age
description: Also, dozens remain trapped after the earthquake in Taiwan.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky signed a law lowering the draft age from 27 to 25 and eliminated some medical exemptions in an effort to replenish Ukraine’s exhausted  army. He also created an electronic database of men, starting at age 17, to crack down on draft dodgers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin
title: Whitney Museum Names Chief Curator
description: Kim Conaty will steer exhibitions and the permanent collection, saying she will pay close attention to work by Latino and Indigenous artists.
content: When Scott Rothkopf, the former deputy director and chief curator of the Whitney Museum of American Art, stepped up as director of the New York institution last fall, he knew he would have to hire his replacement in the curatorial area. That role — one of the most influential in the contemporary art world — will be filled, effective next week, by Kim Conaty, the museum’s curator of drawings and prints since 2017. In her new position she will steer the institution’s permanent collection and acquisitions, as well as its exhibitions and conservation activities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Who ‘Won’ Covid? It Depends How You Measure.
description: Four years after the pandemic began, we’re still learning basic facts about what happened.
content: Twenty months ago, in July 2022, I wrote a long essay sketching what I called the “pretty brutal” endemic future for Covid: probably about 100,000 deaths annually, at least for the next few years. The number was just a ballpark estimate, drawn from modeling by the epidemiologist Trevor Bedford. But as it is turning out, it looks to have been almost exactly right. The official count is that about 170,000 Americans died of Covid over those 20 months, at a pace that suggests at the end of the second year, the total might have been just past 200,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Trump’s Backers Are Determined Not to Blow It This Time Around
description: The right-wing networks Trump can count on are ready for action.
content: In a rare display of unity, more than 100 conservative tax-exempt organizations have joined forces in support of Donald Trump and the MAGA agenda, forming a $2 billion-plus political machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parker Henry
title: It’s a Free Country. For How Much Longer?
description: Three new books explore the complications of liberty and the seductions of authoritarianism in American life.
content: At the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic, amid encouragement to stay at home, a Las Vegas school board candidate’s tweet went viral: “I just went to a crowded Red Robin.” Her reason? “Because this is America. And I’ll do what I want.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Beyoncé Doesn’t Skimp on Flowers
description: In recent weeks, Beyoncé has sent elaborate all-white arrangements to musicians including Jack White, K. Michelle and Nicki Minaj.
content: The expression “to give someone their flowers” means to praise a person and show them care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Canadian Politicians Were Targeted by China in 2021, Report Says
description: Lawmakers testified at a public hearing on foreign interference that they had been caught in China’s cross hairs after criticizing it over human rights.
content: A top-secret intelligence report drafted a week before Canada’s 2021 general election warned about ongoing attempts by the Chinese government to meddle in specific races, saying that Beijing had “identified Canadian politicians considered” to be opponents of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Why Does Steam Float Over the Streets of Manhattan?
description: The orange cylinders that funnel hot vapor up and away serve an important purpose in New York City’s steam system.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at an unlikely New York icon: the orange steam funnels that spew clouds of vapor over the streets of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Intelligence Warning to Moscow Named Specific Target of Attack
description: The C.I.A. told Russia that Islamic State terrorists were plotting an attack on Crocus City Hall, a concert venue.
content: The U.S. warning to Russia ahead of a terrorist attack near Moscow was highly specific: Crocus City Hall was a potential target of the Islamic State, according to U.S. officials.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 3, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, April 3, 2024.
content: An obituary on Saturday about the actor Louis Gossett Jr. misstated the name of the play in which he portrayed the Congolese leader Patrice Lumumba on Broadway in 1971. It is “Murderous Angels,” not “Dangerous Angels.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: How Biden’s White House Gathering for Ramadan Unraveled Over Gaza
description: Some Muslim community leaders said it would be wrong to attend an iftar meal with President Biden while Gaza is under siege.
content: When the White House invited Muslim community leaders for a dinner this week celebrating the holy month of Ramadan, the responses started coming in fast: Decline. Decline. Decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: A Look at Taiwan’s Strongest Earthquakes
description: Earthquakes of similar intensity to the one that hit the island on Wednesday have caused large-scale death and destruction.
content: The magnitude 7.4 earthquake that hit Taiwan on Wednesday morning was the strongest in 25 years, the island’s Central Weather Administration said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Kristen Wiig and Maya Rudolph Just Want You to Like Them
description: Good friends and “Saturday Night Live” alumnae, the actresses are each headlining an Apple TV+ comedy of wealth and status.
content: Sometimes Maya Rudolph will watch a movie and marvel at how miserable an actor looks. “They’re covered in fake blood and broken glass, and they’re crying the whole time,” she said. “I don’t know how people do that for work! That looks so hard and stressful.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How to Conduct a Podcast Interview
description: A winning essay by Matthew Jeong, age 17.
content: This essay, by Matthew Jeong, 17, from Houston, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: How Can Our Friends Choose a Realtor Other Than My Husband?
description: A reader is angered by friends who list their homes with other real estate brokers — sometimes without giving his husband a chance to make his case.
content: My husband is an experienced Realtor. Like many, he has stories of friends who choose not to use him in their real estate transactions. Their excuse is usually that they don’t want to mix business with friendship. (This suggests to me that they don’t believe the friendship is strong enough to weather the experience or that my husband isn’t professional enough to provide top-notch service.) He has lost friends who promised to use him and then didn’t — and others who didn’t even give him a chance to make his case. They have caused him personal and financial pain. One good friend listed her home recently without even telling him. My husband is a sensitive soul, and it angers me to see him hurt by thoughtless friends. Advice?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: How Soccer Learned to Embrace Ramadan: From Faked Injuries to Bespoke Diets
description: In competitions like the Premier League, Muslim pros who once faced pressure to avoid daily fasts during the monthlong holiday now benefit from custom diets and in-game breaks.
content: Youseff Chippo had a secret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Ernesto Londoño
title: He’s on Death Row for Murders. Prison Workers Say He Should Be Spared.
description: Brian Dorsey, who pleaded guilty to murder in the 2006 killings of Sarah and Ben Bonnie, is scheduled to be executed on Tuesday unless Missouri’s governor or the courts step in.
content: Among those asking Missouri’s governor to spare the life of Brian Dorsey, who was convicted of two murders and is set to be executed on Tuesday, were Roman Catholic bishops, law professors and national mental health groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Paul Mozur, Meaghan Tobin and John Yoon
title: Taiwan Quake Damages Buildings and a Highway in Hualien
description: Rescue efforts in the city were centered on two buildings, one of which appeared near collapse. Some roads to the region were cut off.
content: The magnitude 7.4 earthquake that struck Taiwan on Wednesday damaged many buildings and a major highway in Hualien, a city on the eastern coast, and it knocked out power as it rocked the island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: The U.S. Is Rebuilding a Legal Pathway for Refugees. The Election Could Change That.
description: President Biden is restoring resources and staffing for the refugee program, which was gutted during the Trump administration.
content: With national attention focused on the chaos at the southern border, President Biden has been steadily rebuilding a legal pathway for immigration that was gutted during the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Contradicting Trump, Ruby Garcia’s Sister Says He Never Contacted Family
description: The former president held up the death of a young Michigan woman at a campaign rally as an example of what he calls “migrant crime,” and claimed to have spoken to her family.
content: The sister of the young Michigan woman whose killing has become the latest flashpoint for Republicans on illegal immigration is pushing back on former President Donald J. Trump, criticizing him for using her sister’s death to score political points and contradicting his claims that he contacted the family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Alina Lobzina and Tomas Dapkus
title: For Lithuania, Unease Over a Growing Russian-Speaking Diaspora
description: An influx of exiled Russian activists and refugees from Ukraine and Belarus is stirring fears in a country that fought to preserve its language and culture under Soviet occupation.
content: A pile of flowers blanketed a small memorial in the center of the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius after the death of the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny last month. “Putin Is a Murderer,” read a placard in Russian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: virtuoso
description: This word has appeared in 100 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word virtuoso has appeared in 100 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 7 in “Joan Lader Keeps Broadway in Tune” by Alexis Soloski:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: NATO Weighs Taking Over U.S.-Led Group Directing Ukraine Military Aid
description: The proposal faces several obstacles, including whether all members would agree to the changes. But the alliance is worried about wavering American support for Kyiv.
content: With continued American aid to Ukraine stalled and the looming prospect of a second Trump presidency, NATO’s top diplomat said on Wednesday that the alliance was poised to take more control over military support sent to Ukraine — a role that the United States has played for the past two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Traders Are Betting Millions That Trump Media Will Tumble
description: The parent company of Truth Social is a popular target for short-sellers, even after they lost $100 million last month betting on a decline in the stock that didn’t come.
content: Before former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company made its stock market debut, many investors were lining up to bet on its collapse. After the company’s share price plunged following an initial surge, the appetite to bet against the stock has grown even more ravenous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Lauren Boebert Has Blood Clot Removed After Hospitalization for Leg Swelling
description: The far-right firebrand from Colorado, who is part of a slim Republican majority in the House, is expected to make a full recovery, her campaign said.
content: Representative Lauren Boebert, a far-right ally of former President Donald J. Trump from Colorado who is part of the razor-thin Republican majority in the House, had surgery on Tuesday to remove an acute blood clot in her leg, her campaign said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
title: #MeToo Stalled in France. This Actress Might Be Changing Things.
description: Judith Godrèche says the abuse of children and women is stitched into the fabric of the French movie industry. This time, the country seems to be listening more closely.
content: Judith Godrèche did not set out to relaunch the #MeToo movement in France’s movie industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Picks 3 Companies to Help Astronauts Drive Around the Moon
description: The agency’s future moon buggies will reach speeds of 9.3 miles per hour and will be capable of self-driving.
content: NASA will be renting some cool wheels to drive around the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Taiwan Earthquake’s Aftermath
description: See scenes from around the island.
content: A powerful earthquake of at least 7.4 magnitude struck Taiwan shortly before 8 a.m. on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Leader of South Africa’s Assembly Resigns Amid Corruption Allegations
description: The legal problems of Nosiviwe Mapisa-Nqakula expose the governing African National Congress to one of its biggest weaknesses — corruption allegations — ahead of a crucial national election.
content: The speaker of South Africa’s National Assembly resigned on Wednesday, a day after a judge cleared the way for her to be arrested on charges that she took bribes when she served as defense minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Demetri Martin Confronts the Paradoxes of a Veteran Stand-Up Career
description: In his new Netflix special, “Demetri Deconstructed,” he tries a more conceptual approach than the simplicity he was known for.
content: A comedy career can be a tricky puzzle. You must evolve to stay relevant and interesting, but change too much and fans will revolt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Lizzo Says She Is Not Leaving Music Industry After ‘I Quit’ Post
description: Lizzo clarified that she was not quitting music after writing on Instagram last week that she was “starting to feel like the world doesn’t want me in it.”
content: Lizzo, the Grammy Award-winning singer, clarified on Tuesday that she was not quitting the music industry, days after her social media post saying “I QUIT” led some fans to speculate that she was ending her music career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Angel Reese Declares for the W.N.B.A. Draft … in Vogue
description: Athletes like Ms. Reese and Serena Williams know that fashion is now part of the game.
content: L.S.U. may have lost to Iowa in the Elite Eight round of the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament, but even two days afterward their star forward Angel Reese was still making headlines — this time in Vogue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: An English Village Hollowed Out for a Train That May Never Come
description: When Britain cut back a planned high-speed rail line, some residents on the route were pleased. They’re less delighted with what happened next.
content: For those that can afford them, the large villas at Whitmore Heath offer the tranquillity of the countryside within striking distance of urban centers like Stoke-on-Trent and Stafford, an hour’s drive north of Birmingham, the largest city in the English Midlands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Has the FAFSA Delay Changed Your Decisions Around College?
description: We want to hear from readers about how they’re choosing their schools while waiting for financial aid packages.
content: Applying for financial aid was supposed to get easier with the new version of the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, which millions of families and thousands of schools rely on to determine how students will pay for college in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Abortion and the Florida Fakeout
description: Will the state sit the presidential election out, like a retiree watching pickleball?
content: It seemed, for a while there, that 2024 was going to be The Presidential Election Year Without Much Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: What Doctors Want You to Know About Beta Blockers for Anxiety
description: Start-ups are making it easier to get the pills online, but experts warn they should be used with caution.
content: Anxious ahead of a big job interview? Worried about giving a speech? First date nerves?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: A Gender Theorist Who Just Wants Everyone to Get Along
description: Judith Butler’s new book, “Who’s Afraid of Gender?,” tries to turn down the heat on an inflamed argument.
content: As the example of Judith Butler shows, the boons of intellectual celebrity come at a cost. Yes, your work will command the kind of attention that would be the envy of most scholars; but the substance of that work will get eclipsed by your name, and your name will trigger a reaction in people who have never read a single thing you wrote. Throw some misogyny into the mix, and the most scornful attacks can take a lurid turn — even (or especially) if, like Butler, you identify as nonbinary. In 2017, when Butler visited Brazil for a conference on democracy, far-right protesters burned an effigy of Butler dressed in a pink bra and a witch hat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Can Oats Really Help You Lose Weight?
description: A viral TikTok trend touts “Oatzempic” as a weight-loss hack. We asked the experts if there’s anything to it.
content: On TikTok, a woman blends a half cup of rolled oats with a cup of water and the juice of half a lime. She forces a smile and then hesitantly takes a sip. “That,” she says with a colorful flourish, “is nasty.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Jen Poyant, Daniel Ramirez, Pat McCusker, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell and Marion Lozano
title: The Second Best Way to Get Divorced, According to Maya Hawke
description: The “Stranger Things” actor reads an essay about a “nobody-moves-out” breakup and reflects on her own experience growing up with divorced parents.
content: When Maya Hawke’s famous parents got divorced, she was just a little kid trying to navigate their newly separate worlds. Paparazzi aside, Maya’s experience of shuttling between two homes was still more common than the arrangement described in the essay Maya reads: “Our Kinder, Gentler, Nobody-Moves-Out Divorce,” by Jordana Jacobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Election Takeaways: Trump and Biden Win Primaries, but Voters Express Their Discontent
description: Nikki Haley drew a notable slice of Republican voters in four states, while protest votes against the president over his support for Israel continued.
content: Hundreds of thousands of voters turned out in New York for the Democratic and Republican primaries on Tuesday, where President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump won overwhelming victories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Elise Young
title: New Jersey Challenges N.Y.C. Congestion Pricing in Federal Court
description: A closely watched lawsuit could block or upend the city’s new tolling program, which will charge most vehicles for entering the busiest parts of Manhattan.
content: Federal transportation officials allowed New York to move ahead with congestion pricing without fully addressing how traffic and pollution would be shifted to its neighbors across the Hudson River as drivers avoid the new tolls, a lawyer for the State of New Jersey argued in federal court on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Listening to Beyoncé & Future (and the Discourse)
description: How conversation about very specific aspects of the new albums “Cowboy Carter” and “We Don’t Trust You” can obscure talk of their musical quality.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Santul Nerkar
title: Fed Chair Awaits More Inflation Cooling as Path Proves ‘Bumpy’
description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said officials can take their time cutting rates. He also underscored the Fed’s independence as election season heats up.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, reiterated on Wednesday that the central bank can take its time before cutting interest rates as inflation fades and economic growth holds up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By José Andrés
title: José Andrés: Let People Eat
description: You cannot win this war by starving an entire population.
content: In the worst conditions you can imagine — after hurricanes, earthquakes, bombs and gunfire — the best of humanity shows up. Not once or twice but always.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: Jonathan Tetelman Arrives at the Met in ‘La Rondine’
description: The tenor sang the role of Ruggero in a revival of Puccini’s opera that was performed with such restraint, it verged on overly careful.
content: The revival of Nicolas Joël’s Art Deco-inspired production of Puccini’s “La Rondine” at the Metropolitan Opera highlights a quality that Puccini is not necessarily known for: restraint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: I.D.F. Says U.N. Observers in Lebanon Were Wounded by Buried Explosive
description: A spokesman for the Israeli military said the blast was caused “by an explosive previously installed there by Hezbollah,” a Lebanese militia and political movement.
content: A buried explosive device was the source of a blast that injured U.N. military observers in Lebanon over the weekend as they were patrolling the border with Israel, Israel’s military said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Ian Stewart, James Shield and Jessica Metzger
title: Israel Takes Responsibility for Strike That Killed Aid Workers, and Tesla’s Sales Drop
description: Plus, the fight to see the eclipse.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: More Than Many Realized, the Bridge Connected All of Baltimore
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 3, 2024.
content: “Every single Baltimorean felt that bridge fall down. That’s our London Bridge. That’s our Golden Gate Bridge. It was like a friend constantly saying hello to me in the morning.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Christopher Durang, the Surrealist of Snark
description: In works like “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” the playwright would force you to laugh, not to dull the pain but to hone it.
content: Pickpocketing Chekhov for dramatic capital is almost a rite of passage among playwrights, but only Christopher Durang invested the loot in beefcake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Rosenbloom
title: Traveling Light: How to Pack a Carry-on
description: Should you fold or roll your clothes? Is a duffel bag better than a backpack or a bag with wheels? How to pack light and avoid checked-bag fees (not to mention lost luggage).
content: For some travelers, the mere thought of packing a carry-on bag can sour even the most potent vacation anticipation. But packing light can also be a creative endeavor that helps build excitement for your upcoming getaway. And with fees for checked bags on the rise, it makes economic sense to master the art of packing a carry-on. Here are some tips on how to save space — and your sanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and William K. Rashbaum
title: Judge Won’t Delay Trump’s Criminal Trial to Wait for Immunity Ruling
description: The former president had asked the judge to push back his Manhattan criminal trial, slated to begin April 15, until after the Supreme Court decides whether he is immune from prosecution.
content: The judge overseeing Donald J. Trump’s criminal case in Manhattan rejected his last-ditch bid to delay a trial beyond April 15, removing on Wednesday one of the final obstacles to the first prosecution of a former American president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Benjamin Mullin
title: Apollo Valued Paramount at $26 Billion in Overture That Was Ignored
description: Paramount’s board of directors, which was already deep into talks with the media company Skydance, didn’t engage with the offer.
content: As Paramount, the media company that’s the home of the “Top Gun” franchise and Nickelodeon, was preparing to enter exclusive talks to sell itself to the media company Skydance, another suitor emerged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Vishakha Darbha and Jillian Weinberger
title: Could Trump Financially Ruin the G.O.P.?
description: The Republican Party is in disarray. The former president and his mounting legal woes are to blame.
content: The G.O.P. has a Donald Trump money problem. The former president is facing multiple indictments, and fighting those legal battles hasn’t been cheap. Unfortunately for Trump — and the Republican Party — big donors have noticed and are losing interest in filling the G.O.P.’s draining coffers. That means trouble for states like Michigan and Arizona, which are in desperate need of party money for down-ballot races.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Byrne and Carole K. Hooven
title: The Problem With Saying ‘Sex Assigned at Birth’
description: The term creates doubt about a biological fact when there shouldn’t be any.
content: As you may have noticed, “sex” is out, and “sex assigned at birth” is in. Instead of asking for a person’s sex, some medical and camp forms these days ask for “sex assigned at birth” or “assigned sex” (often in addition to gender identity). The American Medical Association and the American Psychological Association endorse this terminology; its use has also exploded in academic articles. The Cleveland Clinic’s online glossary of diseases and conditions tells us that the “inability to achieve or maintain an erection” is a symptom of sexual dysfunction, not in “males,” but in “people assigned male at birth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Donovan
title: Life Gave a Pastry Chef Lemons. She Made Lemon Bars.
description: These sunny, sweet-tart treats have a little twist: a rich pecan short crust.
content: I’m from a lush land. Green abounds in the South. Our climate is so dewy, so thick, that we learn how to breathe through our skin down here. The nearly neon green kudzu, not just a romantic notion, climbs. The vines creep over our lives, over corners, around hills, down slopes, into gutters. We pulse with the heat. We sit with the rain during our summer storms. We ride out hurricanes with rum. We stop and listen to the cicadas when they request our audience every number of years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Frustrated Prosecutors Ask Trump Documents Judge to Act on Key Claim
description: The push for a quick decision on one of the former president’s most far-fetched claims is an unusual and risky move in a case Judge Aileen Cannon has allowed to become bogged down.
content: In an open display of frustration, federal prosecutors on Tuesday night told the judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case that a “fundamentally flawed” order she had issued was causing delays and asked her to quickly resolve a critical dispute about one of Mr. Trump’s defenses — leaving them time to appeal if needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas National Guard Member Charged With Migrant Smuggling
description: The arrest marked at least the second time in the last year that National Guard members in Texas had been caught trying to transport migrants from the border.
content: A silver sport utility vehicle, driving at speeds of more than 100 miles per hour, led the police on a 15-mile chase over the weekend near the U.S. border with Mexico in an area that has long been popular with migrant smugglers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Nebraska Republicans Renew Push for ‘Winner Take All’ Electoral System
description: In 2020, Joseph R. Biden Jr. won one electoral vote in a state that divides its votes by congressional district. Donald J. Trump has supported the stalled effort to change the system.
content: A renewed push by Nebraska Republicans to move to a “winner-take-all” system in presidential elections has raised the prospect that the 2024 contest could end in an electoral college tie — with the House of Representatives deciding the winner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: The Best Way to Ring In Spring? Herby Chicken and Noodles
description: Balanced with an asparagus-beet salad and a simple citrusy dessert, this dinner from David Tanis has all the best of early spring.
content: The tips of deciduous trees are showing the barest tinge of green, and flowering fruit trees are in full bloom. A neighbor’s forsythia has come to life, bulbs are busily doing their thing. Spring has arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Zelensky Lowers Ukraine’s Draft Age, Risking Political Backlash
description: The idea of requiring more men to join the fight against Russia’s invasion has become toxic, but Russia is not relenting in its assault.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has signed into law three measures aimed at replenishing the ranks of his country’s exhausted and battered army, including the politically poisonous step of lowering the age when men become eligible for mobilization, and eliminating some medical exemptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: New York Prisoners, Denied a Solar Eclipse Viewing, Sue the State
description: Six men at an upstate New York prison said that the eclipse had religious significance and that a statewide lockdown order preventing them from watching it violated their rights.
content: When the moon crosses in front of the sun on Monday afternoon and, for a few minutes, casts a shadow over much of New York State, millions of people will be able to witness the rare celestial event just by looking up. Inmates in the state’s prisons will not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Tallerico
title: The Various Mr. Ripleys
description: “Ripley” on Netflix is the latest riff on the con-artist character the author Patricia Highsmith invented in the 1950s. Here’s a look at the earlier versions.
content: One of fiction’s most famous impostors returns on Thursday with the debut of Netflix’s “Ripley,” the latest adaptation of a character invented in the 1950s by the author Patricia Highsmith. In eight episodes, all written and directed by the Oscar-winning screenwriter Steven Zaillian (“Schindler’s List,” “The Night Of”), a classic chameleon changes colors yet again, returning to a few core elements of Highsmith’s original creation while also boosting the creepiness quotient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Seven aid workers killed in Gaza.
content: Israeli strikes on a marked World Central Kitchen aid convoy in the Gaza Strip killed seven aid workers, fanning international outrage and underscoring the risks to humanitarian workers trying to fend off famine. The workers were hit despite having coordinated their movements with the Israeli military, the charity said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Everybody Wants a Piece of South Carolina’s $1.8 Billion Surplus. Is It Real?
description: Whom does it belong to? How did it get there? Why? The more legislators dig, the murkier things seem to get.
content: South Carolina recently discovered that $1.8 billion of state money has been sitting in a bank account for more than five years, and no one seems to know its origin or what it was intended for. Now lawmakers are looking for answers, but the more they dig, the murkier it seems to get.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Breyer
title: Stephen Breyer: The Supreme Court I Served On Was Made Up of Friends
description: If justices who disagree so profoundly can do so respectfully, perhaps it is possible for our politically divided country to do the same.
content: Recently, the Supreme Court justices Sonia Sotomayor and Amy Coney Barrett spoke together publicly about how members of the court speak civilly to one another while disagreeing, sometimes vigorously, about the law. Considerable disagreements on professional matters among the Supreme Court justices, important as they are, remain professional, not personal. The members of the court can and do get along well personally. That matters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin
title: A New Way of Looking at the Nude
description: The artists redefining portraits of the human body for a more inclusive age.
content: THE ARTIST PAUL Cadmus was flipping through Modern Maturity, the AARP’s official magazine, in 1991 when he saw something that made him angry. A disgruntled reader had written a letter to the editor slamming the publication for reproducing the Italian Renaissance artist Masaccio’s famous painting of Adam and Eve without including the fig leaves that church officials later added to cover their genitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Son of Dominican Republic Politician Is Fatally Shot in Houston, Police Say
description: Luis Alfredo Pacheco Rojas, 34, son of Alfredo Pacheco, the president of the Chamber of Deputies of the Dominican Republic, was killed on Monday in a drive-by shooting, the authorities said.
content: The son of a politician from the Dominican Republic was fatally shot outside a gas station in Houston on Monday night in what the police said they believed was a “targeted” drive-by shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Food Aid for Gazans Was Sent Back to Cyprus
description: Also, Ukraine lowered its draft age. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: World Central Kitchen, the charity group that paused its operations in Gaza this week after seven of its workers were killed in an Israeli strike, sent three ships with hundreds of tons of food meant for Gazans back to port in Cyprus. It was the most tangible sign yet that the attack, which Israel called a mistake, has set back efforts to address severe hunger that experts say is approaching famine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Donald Trump and the Justice System
description: Readers discuss how the former president is or is not getting special treatment. Also: The killing of aid workers in Gaza; screens in the classroom.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: How a Snake Uses Its Sense of Smell
description: These reptiles and their social networks are understudied, according to researchers applying scents to different snakes to assess their behavior.
content: Say the words “animal self-recognition,” and many scientists will think of chimpanzees, crows and elephants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Is Your Garden Missing Something? You May Need a Large Pot (or Several).
description: An imposing work of pottery can be as important to the design of a landscape as any well-placed plant. And no, we’re not talking about flower pots.
content: Flower pots, they are not. But Stephen Procter’s large stoneware garden vessels, some as tall as five feet and incorporating 250 pounds of clay, are nevertheless functional pottery — even without the soil and the plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: The ‘Awkwardness and Uncertainty’ of Unregulated Sperm Donation
description: A New York Times documentary follows sperm donors and recipients who operate outside of the fertility industry.
content: Tyree Kelly stands in an empty parking lot in the Phoenix area, a faded Macy’s logo still visible on the abandoned mall behind him. He paces, checking his phone and leaving voice mail messages for the woman he is supposed to meet. But she never shows up. Which is frustrating for Mr. Kelly, given how in-demand he says his sperm is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: Eli Noyes, Animator Who Turned Clay and Sand Into Art, Dies at 81
description: His innovative stop-motion animation influenced a generation of filmmakers, including the creators of Wallace and Gromit.
content: Eli Noyes, a filmmaker whose use of clay and sand in stop-motion animation garnered an Oscar nomination and shaped the aesthetic of Nickelodeon and MTV during the early days of cable television, died on March 23 at his home in San Francisco. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: For Len Cariou, Dying Onstage Each Night Has Been ‘Invigorating’
description: In “Tuesdays With Morrie,” the 84-year-old actor was eager to tackle “a rich role in a show that asks, ‘What if despair and death are not the end?’”
content: Chris Domig was ready to throw in the towel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: How a Pandemic Boom Led to a ‘Property Tax Mess’ in Colorado
description: A surge of new residents into Rocky Mountain states drove up home prices. The result was property tax increases of 40 percent or more for some of those already there.
content: Marleen Gamble had already taken out a reverse mortgage on her townhouse in 2018 to keep up with the steady increase in expenses eating into the Social Security checks that are her only source of income.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher and Nina Westervelt
title: Partying on a Tuesday With Elon Musk and His 3-Year-Old
description: Futurists and the future-curious, including Seth Meyers and Darren Aronofsky, attended a screening in New York City for a new PBS documentary.
content: The future looked bright despite the rain on Tuesday evening at the Museum of Modern Art, where guests — including Elon Musk and Seth Meyers — gathered for a screening of a new PBS documentary series, “A Brief History of the Future.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Erica L. Green
title: ‘Stop It Now’: Jill Biden Privately Urges an End to Conflict in Gaza
description: The president recounted the first lady’s concerns as he was pressed about the war at a meeting with Muslim community members.
content: One of the strongest voices inside the White House urging an end to civilian casualties in Gaza is the person closest to the president: Jill Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
title: Biden Is ‘Outraged.’ But Is He Willing to Use America’s Leverage With Israel?
description: President Biden, at least in public, has limited his responses to Israel’s war in Gaza to ever more indignant declarations.
content: When President Biden said he was “outraged and heartbroken” about the killing of seven World Central Kitchen aid workers in Gaza, his forceful language raised a natural question: Would this strike, even if a tragic error, lead him to put conditions on the weapons he sends to Israel?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Dynamic Storm Brings Heavy, Wet Snow and Strong Winds to New England
description: Snow in April is not uncommon, a meteorologist said, but this storm comes after a recent stretch of warmer spring weather across the Northeast.
content: A storm system that was already delivering significant amounts of springtime snow to parts of the Great Lakes region this week moved east on Wednesday, bringing heavy snow, soaking rains and high winds from northern New York State through northern New England, the National Weather Service said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Two Shakespearean Triumphs in Paris, or a Plague on Both Their Houses?
description: New productions of “Macbeth” and “Hamlet” follow a French tradition of adapting familiar works. The results are innovative, and sometimes cryptic.
content: Two Paris playhouses, both alike in dignity, putting on rival new Shakespeare productions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: The M.T.A. Wants Marathon Runners to Pay Bridge Tolls, Too
description: The New York City Marathon is being asked to pay roughly $750,000 a year to make up for toll revenue lost while the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge is closed.
content: At the start of every New York City Marathon, runners fill the upper and lower tiers of the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge, an arresting sight that conveys the immensity of the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Spring Holidays
description: Do you observe any religious holidays during the season?
content: Are you observing any religious or spiritual holidays this spring, like Ramadan, Passover or Easter? If so, how do you and your family celebrate? Why is this tradition meaningful to you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Patient With Transplanted Pig Kidney Leaves Hospital for Home
description: Richard Slayman, 62, is the first patient to receive a kidney from a genetically modified pig. Two weeks after the procedure, he was well enough to be discharged, doctors said.
content: The first patient to receive a kidney transplanted from a genetically modified pig has fared so well that he was discharged from the hospital on Wednesday, just two weeks after the groundbreaking surgery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe and Bea Malsky
title: Map: 7.4-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Taiwan
description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
content: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: George Santos May Not Be in the House, but He’s in Your Springtime Quiz
description: Pep up your entry into April with a politics quiz.
content: Pep up your entry into April with a politics quiz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘The Iron Giant’ and More
description: I cover the Supreme Court for The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying recently.
content: I cover the Supreme Court for The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying recently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Kelso
title: Powerful Earthquake Shakes Taiwan
description: The magnitude-7.4 quake was followed by more than 200 aftershocks.
content: The magnitude-7.4 quake was followed by more than 200 aftershocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kassie Bracken, Kristen Williamson and Christina Kelso
title: Inside World Central Kitchen’s Work in Gaza
description: World Central Kitchen has suspended its relief efforts in Gaza after seven aid workers were killed in Israeli airstrikes on Monday. Videos reveal the challenges of food distribution in a territory under siege.
content: World Central Kitchen has suspended its relief efforts in Gaza after seven aid workers were killed in Israeli airstrikes on Monday. Videos reveal the challenges of food distribution in a territory under siege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Associated Press and Storyful
title: Storm Leaves Trail of Destruction in the Midwest
description: Severe weather toppled campers and trees in Ohio and Kentucky as parts of West Virginia were placed under tornado watch.
content: Severe weather toppled campers and trees in Ohio and Kentucky as parts of West Virginia were placed under tornado watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Powerful Earthquake Shakes Taiwan
description: The quake, with a magnitude of at least 7.4, caused landslides and severe damage to some buildings.
content: The quake, with a magnitude of at least 7.4, caused landslides and severe damage to some buildings.
source.name: The New York Times
